short answer, the easy way to do it is to sleep abnormally (i.e., not as a single 8hr session), and stick with it
during high school, i would immediately take a long nap (like 3+ hours) after coming home at 3pm, wake up at dinner time, fall asleep a couple hours past midnight to wake up at 7ish. when i sleep the second time, i would be on my BACK, this being easier to achieve when i was dead tired. this set-up should make it easier to slip consciously into sleep paralysis, and from there transition into a lucid dream

We don't get that much snow or ice here so we're not really prepared for how to deal with it when it does happen. Main roads aren't too bad thanks to the traffic on them but small and hilly cul-de-sacs and driveways are a fucking nightmare and some people like to get driveways of fancy ornamental stone that looks lacquered and nice, but is a deathtrap with even 0.1% snow or ice on it.
As for actual grit or whatever, main roads get some after a few hours if you're lucky and only for snow, while there's two grit bins for one particularly nasty hill I rarely see any grit from them spread out when it's snowy or icy, I'm guessing the grit in them has gotten rock solid over the years. A few people put a bit of grit on their pathways if you're lucky but it's about 1 in 50 people and a few try their luck with builder's sand, which is worthless.

posts.sub: Mouse Maid from Touhou Wiggling Around
posts.com:
Good morning /wsr/!

I made Kurumi MaidCard which is a means of image based software distribution. The attached image actually contains the full code of Kurumi MaidCard (it is in that square that looks like TV static).

I have a small program which does nothing but trick a Windows computer into thinking the mouse is constantly moving. You can run it all day and it has no impact on you as a user. Your mouse never visibly moves at all, but chat programs that monitor "away" status will never show you as away. It works because Windows is dumb and if you tell it to move the mouse to the mouse's current location, that is sufficient to be counted as moving the mouse.

I made it to give wagies a brief taste of freedom before companies start enforcing camera use with eyeball tracking AI that can rat you out for not looking at your monitor all day.

I plan to distribute it in a MaidCard. Touhou has a mouse maid and I like the mouse maid and I want a PNG image of the mouse maid wiggling around for it. A hula hoop would be ideal. Subsequent posts will contain images of the mouse maid. If I can't get an image of her using a hula hoop or wiggling for some other reason, I will just use one of her in a maid dress.

I will probably call the program Nazrin MaidWiggle.

Thank you /wsr/ for reading my post.

Thank you for nice words fren. The intention of the Kurumi MaidCard isn't to make the file size of code smaller. It is to put it in a PNG image so that it is recognizable at a glance by looking at a thumbnail of the image and also to use the PNG itself as the distribution mechanism so I can post larger multi-file projects on 4chan in one image and not have to use GitHub for any reason or make 500 pastebins for every single class, or use a silly architecture where one file has 500 classes to make it more distributable by pastebin.

Maid Cards have compression of just the file data, and the purpose was to make the File Data Maid Address take less space on the Maid Sticker (decorative part of the card).

You are correct that a 4MB image might be like a million times bigger than just posting the text of the code, but Kurumi MaidCard is intended more for using the image is a container so that distributing code becomes less centralized and more convenient. Anywhere you can post a PNG image that doesn't mess with the dimensions of the image or the pixels of it is now a software distribution system, no GitHub required.

A lot of people ask why not just use GitHub? My answer is that there is no reason you should have to give Microsoft a bunch of personal data to post code on the internet, or accept any kind of Terms of Service from the distribution platform.

The only Terms of Service I will accept from a Computer Program are that I will dictate my terms to it, and it will serve them. Failing that, I will build alternatives.

If you look at the Warosu thread you can see I put a cookbook in a Maid Card. If a Maid Card can hold a cookbook it can also hold code for a non-trivial project like a compiler.

The original show, Zeta, Double Zeta, and then Char's Counterattack is a real good place to start but it's also (from what I've seen and know about what I haven't seen) the only real series of shows you probably want to be sure to watch in order (aside from obvious things like Seed Destiny being a sequel to Seed). Wing's a flawed show but it has a lot to like about it as well, so as anon said that'd probably be a pretty good starting point as it doesn't relate to any other shows except its own short sequel Endless Waltz, so you're not in for the long haul or anything. There are film versions of the original show that I feel most people would tell you are worse than the series, I haven't seen them myself, but they present a much shorter version of it if you're not super into it but would like to see it nonetheless and would help a lot if you wanted to go to Zeta from there. You could also check out 08th MS team for a shorter OVA entry (13 episodes) as well if that interests you.
As I said the original's a great show if there's nothign you particular want out of a Gundam show, but if you have anything specific in mind I can try and help you with that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1307548
I'll give you a rundown on Batman comics. Here's the first thing you should know though: DC comics runs on a floating timeline that is constantly being offset by "crisis events" which reset and rearrange the timeline. The point I'm making is simply: don't get TOO caught up on continuity and "proper order." A lot of people go into comics thinking they'll start with book one, and it will be the origin of the hero, and then it will progress in a linear way until the end. That's not the case. Often, characters are introduced with no origin at all, and only later is an origin given to them.
Anyway, peak Batman is the 80s work of Frank Miller, The Dark Knight Returns and Batman: Year One. The Dark Knight Returns isn't canon and was never meant to be, it was meant as a tribute to Batman's long (40 years, at the time) history, as well as a reimagining of a lot of aspects of his story. Like I say, it's non-canon, but it is so great that it influenced basically every Batman story after, and there was a definite time in the 80s/90s where Batman comics did seem to be working towards The Dark Knight Returns as an endpoint. If you've seen the Batman movies, 90% of reading The Dark Knight Returns will be going "oh, that's where that comes from." I highly recommend it.
After The Dark Knight Returns was a huge success, Frank Miller was called in to write Batman's canon new origin. Batman: Year One. This is, as the title suggests, his first year as Batman. It's one of the most acclaimed comics, and was a huge influence on Batman Begins and The Batman.
You said "ideally, something in print." Unfortunately, Legends Of The Dark Knight is largely out of print, but it was a 90s comic line set as a bunch of early Batman stories, many tying into Batman: Year One.
Batman: The Man Who Laughs (do NOT confuse it with The Batman Who Laughs, different thing) is intended to be a direct sequel to Batman: Year One, about Batman's first confrontation with the Joker.

posts.com:
>>1307659
Batman: The Man Who Laughs is also a kind of rewrite of Joker's first appearance from 1940 in Batman #1. There are a few comics that try to rewrite early Batman adventures in the continuity after Year One. Batman and the Monster Men and Batman and the Mad Monk are both rewrites of early early Batman comics from 1939. Unfortunately, not collected.
You said "preferably in print." The things I've listed so far that are definitely in print are The Dark Knight Returns, Batman: Year One, and Batman: The Man Who Laughs.
Batman: Venom is an early adventure from Legends Of The Dark Knight, and I believe it is still in print (I'm sorry if I'm wrong). It was written to introduce the drug venom for the origin of Bane.
Anyway, enough early adventures. The next stuff you oughta read is the 90s work of Jeph Loeb and Tim Sale. Haunted Knight is optional, that is just a collection of some comics they wrote together. Batman: The Long Halloween and Batman: Dark Victory are not optional. They present Batman's second year and the origin of Robin. They're also acclaimed as some of the best Batman comics ever. Some people would tell you to skip all that other stuff I mentioned, and just read Year One, Long Halloween, then Dark Victory.
After Dark Victory, there's a direct sequel by a different team named Robin: Year One. The sequel to Robin: Year One is Batgirl: Year One. The sequel to Batgirl: Year One is Nightwing: Year One. I believe all of these are in print.
Now I say you should go back in time a bit. Read Englehart and Rogers run in Detective comics, which was collected together as Strange Apparitions. And read either the full O’Neil/Adams run (I think there’s an omnibus now), or at least read the saga of Ras Al Ghul (which is collected in various books, such as Batman Arkham: Ra's Al Ghul or Batman Vs Ras Al Ghul).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1307666
Also, try to get any kind of collected best of edition, there are many. I really like the decades collections, "Batman In The Forties" "Batman In The Fifties" "Batman In The Sixties" etc. They go up to the 80s. DC recently reprinted and expanded on Batman In The Fifties, I don't know if they're going to do every decade. There's also collections that are specific to certain characters, like "The Joker: His Greatest Jokes" which collects Joker stories from the 40s to the modern age. "Batman: The Bat and the Cat: 80 Years of Romance." "The Joker: 80 Years of the Clown Prince of Crime." "Detective Comics: 80 Years of Batman." These collections will help fill in gaps you're missing.
Two major comics I haven't mentioned yet, both from the 80s: Batman: The Killing Joke by Alan Moore, and Arkham Asylum: A Serious House On Serious Earth by Grant Morrison. The Killing Joke is, to many, the definitive Joker story, and it influenced heavily Batman 1989, The Dark Knight, and Joker 2019. Arkham Asylum influenced the video games of the same name, it's a surreal dreamlike story about the history of the famous asylum.
A Death In The Family (don't confuse with Death Of The Family, different things) shows Joker killing the second Robin, Jason Todd. Batman: A Lonely Place of Dying, isn't in print anymore, but it introduces the third Robin, Tim Drake.
Dick Grayson was Robin from 1940 all the way up to the mid 80s, and he still appeared in comics set in the past. Tim Drake was the Robin of the 90s and 2000s. Jason Todd was only Robin for a brief few years. Later, Jason Todd came back from the dead.
Knightfall is the major event of the 90s, where Tim Drake is a hugely important character. After Knightfall, No Man's Land. Hush goes here. Under The Hood brings you the return of Jason Todd. Grant Morrison's seven year Batman run (collected in three Omnibus books) basically set the status quo for Batman stories going forward.

In 2011, DC rebooted again. New 52. So you have Scott Snyder's run. The Court Of Owls is the first story of this era. After that, Death Of The Family. I read them, I wasn't a fan. But a lot of people are fans, so it's hard to just say ignore it all. After the new 52 came Rebirth in 2016, which made the new continuity be a mix of new 52 and pre-new 52 comics.
Batman: Black And White is an anthology series of black and white Batman stories by a variety of writers and artists. It's non-canon, some are reinterpretations of the characters, some could be canon they just happen to not be officially, but they're great. Also, collected, well worth reading.
Gotham By Gaslight is a Batman story set in the 1800s. Batman vs Jack The Ripper
Batman Year 100 is a futuristic reinterpretation of Batman in a far off dystopian future.
There are tie-in comics for every cartoon. Batman: The Animated Series actually has three. The Batman Adventures, Batman And Robin Adventures, and Batman: The Adventures Continue. The Batman cartoon had The Batman Strikes. Batman: The Brave And The Bold had one with the same name. Beware The Batman had 13 issues. Batman: The Animated Series cartoon spawned a whole continuity called the DCAU, the DC Animated Universe, comprising itself, Batman Beyond, Superman: The Animated Series, Justice League, Justice League Unlimited, and a few spinoffs. The DCAU has its own fanbase, who consider it the definitive version of the characters. It's pretty good.

>>1307902
>I definitely get what you said about continunity not being too concrete, but if things follow on from others I might as well I feel like.
Reading stories in order is nice, the big thing that trips people up is that retcons typically occur in bits and pieces, not all at once.
To clarify further, Batman’s original origin appeared in Detective Comics #33, and Robins appeared in Detective Comics #38. Both are comics from 1939 and 40. After, these origins were slowly added to over the years, culminating in 1980’s The Untold Legend Of The Dark Knight, which mixed every single origin together into one story.
In 1986, Batman Year One came out. Okay, so Batman has a new origin. Robin didn’t get a new origin for a few years, so the canon was Batman’s origin from Year One, Robin’s origin from the earlier, pre-crisis comics.
So then, they made a sequel to Batman Year One, called Batman Year Two. A sequel to that was named Batman Year Three, and Batman Year Three was the new canon origin of Robin.
Later, they made The Long Halloween. The Long Halloween details Batman’s second year as Batman, with no reference to the events of Year Two. Because The Long Halloween was so popular, it replaced Year Two as the definitive “year two” story. Year Three was still canon. But then, Dark Victory, a sequel to Long Halloween, was made, and it presents a different version of the events of Robins origin. So Dark Victory replaced Year Three as the definitive “year three” story.
Frank Miller later wrote a sequel to Batman Year One, named All Star Batman And Robin The Boy Wonder. It was received terribly, people didn’t like it. It failed to replace Long Halloween and Dark Victory.
However, you can read any series you choose. Start with Year One, then decide what sequels you want to read for yourself. But know that most comics, if they refer back to the events of Batman’s second and third years, will reference Long Halloween and Dark Victory.

Decode this: ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK

A Twitter snowflake ID is a 64-bit binary number, with 41 bits representing a timestamp, 10 bits representing a machine ID, and 12 bits representing a per-machine sequence number. The snowflake ID is generally serialized in decimal format and is used in the post URL.

For example,
https://twitter.com/i/status/1581674019991916545
Decoding 1581674019991916545:
{'creation_time_milliseconds': 1665935447105,
'datacenter_id': 10,
'machine_id': 337,
'sequence_id': 1,
'server_id': 17}

The filename of a Twitter photo also contains a base64-encoded snowflake ID. This can be decoded into a regular snowflake ID, although it contains three "extra" unknown bytes.
For example,
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q?format=jpg
FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q -> 1572620320212922371

It is unknown if the filename of a Twitter video also contains a snowflake ID. You can see the URL contains it, but any off-platform video would would only contain the file name.
For example,
https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1564378065198882816/pu/vid/960x720/ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK.mp4

How would "ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK" be decoded into a snowflake, if it's possible?

Resources:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowflake_ID
https://discord.com/developers/docs/reference#snowflakes (good visualizations, twitter uses another epoch)
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xVrPoNutyqTdQ04DXBEZW4ZW4A5RAQW2he7qIpTmG-M/edit

>>1307398
Longtime remote dev here. Your story sounds kinda familiar to mine. A while back I really just did not have what I needed to get the sort of jobs I wanted. Here's a bit of what I learned - hope it helps.

1. tl;dr Lie about your accomplishments, not your abilities.
I got turned down pretty frequently cuz I wasn't sure how to sell myself to an employer. You want to start getting interviews while also feeling better about your abilities, try this: exaggerate a little about your accomplishments, but be brutally honest about your limitations. I've been part of the interview process for several of the developers on my team and mentored several of them too, and it's ALWAYS easier to work with someone who can recognize when they're in over their head. Employers aren't scared off by someone if they don't have a degree, they're scared off by someone who's ambiguous about what their abilities are. If I can clearly see you've got the bare-ass fundamentals of C and jack shit else, I at least know that I can put you in some low-risk position while you learn so you don't fuck everything up. On the other hand, if you brag about socket manipulation but start to falter if I ask you about memory scope, you've demonstrated that you have just enough knowledge to introduce massive vulnerabilities into production code, without any of the knowledge required to even recognize them, let alone avoid them. No one's gonna take that risk.

2. tl;dr Prove you can back up your claims.
A degree matters probably a lot less in compsci than you would imagine if an alternative means of assessing your ability is available. A public GitHub or other easy-to-access repository of real work that you've done can neatly substitute for a degree. Do demo projects, do personal projects, submit a link to them with your resume. Formal education is certainly going to give you a big advantage, and also demonstrates that at minimum you've probably been introduced to coding best practices, but you're not...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1307673
...out of luck without it. If you REALLY want to grab an advantage on the same level as a degree, though, start doing some certifications. Some of these come with courses, some with costs attached, but if you've got them, anyone can tell at a glance how much of your resume is bravado and how much you can actually deliver on. LinkedIn also offers a lot of free "certifications" - they're just short tests on some of the principles and concepts that are important to a given coding language, but they're surprisingly in depth, and I look for them when I'm doing interviews. (Also, if you don't know how to use GitHub, learn! It's really easy - Google "git no deep shit", and use the guide in the first link to get started. Version control software is a staple of pretty much any tech company you want to work for.)

3. tl;dr Pick what you want and chase it.
I don't know if this is a problem for you like it was for me, but I'm a hardcore C/C++ developer (SDL fuck yeah, I'm making a game too) and I was absolutely inundated with job offers for JS, Java, .NET, and a whole slew of others. Applying for them early in my career was one of the worst mistakes I ever made, and led to a lot of very embarrassing interviews, several unfulfilling stints in shit positions, and two soul-crushing, zero-warning terminations. Just cuz there's a ton of options doesn't make them worth your while. If you want to work C, you've got to go find jobs that are coding strictly in C, and make it clear during your application, interview, and second interview that you're ONLY looking to code in C. Ditto for SQL or whatever you want to do. If you happened to make an update to some .NET code years ago, don't sell yourself as a .NET developer. You're going to undermine yourself that way by pretending to be something you're not, and it's going to bite your ass and shake your confidence in the languages you actually know how to use. Focus!

posts.name: Anonymous

4. tl;dr Fuck Indeed.
Fuck Indeed. Use LinkedIn if you want to mass-apply, but your best bet genuinely is the company websites. Also: if you find a position that actually interests you, and is more than just another thing to throw a resume at, take the time to do a little research and learn the name of at least one of the people who will see your application. Stick that in your cover letter; it carries a lot of weight.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1307864
“Is that why” is actually a pretty common way to phrase sarcasm, it’s used when someone makes a statement, and then you call it into question by saying “is that why [something which wouldn’t be true if the initial statement was true]”
Here are a few examples:
>I have been trying to eat healthier lately
>Is that why I saw you eating McDonald’s yesterday?
>she can’t come to the phone right now, she isn’t in
>is that why I can see her car parked in her driveway?
>the broken heater has been fixed, it’s working now
>is that why I’m wearing two sweaters, and am still cold?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1306840
So there's a few things to understand about torrenting. Fundamentally, a torrent is just a "secret" link to a file on someone else' device.

We torrent using clients that can help your computer find other people downloading the same "secret" link so you can help each other download the file faster. I can't recommend a specific client to use since I don't actually torrent all that much, but generally doing some research on google and reddit can help you find a decent one. Just do your homework and make sure the program you intend to use hasn't been linked to malware or scams of any kind.

So, let's say you have a torrent client and now want a movie. You're gonna need one of those "secret" links. People track these links on sites called "trackers", where thousands are saved and categorized. You usually have the option, when choosing a link to download a torrent file directly or use a magnet link, most of the time either one will work but I legitimately don't know which is better to use.

Finding a tracker can be tricky, and obscure subjects can be pretty hard to find, but one of the best ways to find a high-quality torrent community is to use private trackers. They're private to keep out undesirables: people that don't seed and bots that reports the swarm to the ISPs. Usually you'll needed to be invited or buy your way in, sometimes smaller ones that need users will have open sign-up periods but they'll close right back up in the blink of an eye. I don't even know of any good private trackers to try and get into, but I've heard that they're out there.

I've mentioned a couple times that I don't torrent, but I do get nearly any movie I want a few clicks away. I'm a part of a private filesharing group that uploads files onto the various free file upload websites like MEGA, Pixeldrain, and Anonfiles. Instead of having a tracker, we have a forum and a discord, and invites must be bought. I think it's a superior form of piracy, personally.

First of all, install uBlock Origin on your browser:
ublockorigin.com
Torrenting sites usually have annoying and potentially dangerous ads.

You'll also want a video player, like:
https://www.videolan.org/vlc/

Download pretty much any torrent program, for example:
https://www.tixati.com/download/

Install it, go to settings and choose a download folder.

Go to a torrenting site and search for a movie or show, for example:
1337x.to
rarbg.to/torrents

When you find the torrent you want, click on the magnet link. It'll send you to the torrent program and ask you if you want to download stuff. You can choose which files to download, if it includes multiple subtitles you can deselect those.

Sometimes you have to include the year, or season (use "season 1" or "s01").
You'll probably want to include "1080p" as well.
You'll notice some say x264 or x265. The former runs on pretty much anything, but files are larger. The latter may not work on your device, but if it does it's usually the better option.
There are a few more things to look out for or to keep in mind, but this should be enough to get you started.

When you're downloading a torrent, you're not downloading from a central server or anything, you're downloading from the file from other peoples computers. They're the peers.
If those people switch off their computers or stop seeding (making the file available to download), then you won't be able to download anything until they return
The popular torrents have loads of seeders so this is less of an issue, but if you're trying to download niche stuff you can run into this problem more

Try downloading and opening the .torrent file instead of clicking the magnet link, but chances are it's dead. The file includes tracker metadata to start downloading.
>>1307701
When you search for a torrent, you'll see how many seeds and peers it has, usually in green and red respectively. Seeders have the entire torrent downloaded, and now they're sharing it with everyone else. Peers are downloading it, but are also sharing what they have with the other peers. So say you add a torrent and it only has 2 peers at the moment, and they're both at 80%. They already shared what they had with each other, and now all you can get is that same 80% and will have to wait until someone with the rest opens their torrent client.

posts.com:
How to solve this problem ? https://codeforces.com/contest/342/problem/A
I know the only possible combinations are : (1,2,4) ; (1,2,6) ; (1,3,6) and if you have 7's or 5's you cannot divide them into groups of three.
How do you choose the numbers in a greedy way ?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: bump

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1307376
Let n be the amount of digits and n_d be the number of occurances of digit d.
The only valid combinations are (1 2 4), (1 2 6) and (1 3 6). This gives several constraints.
5 and 7 do not appear, so n_5 = n_7 = 0.
1 appears in all three, so n_1 = n/3.
4 appears only in the first group, so this group must be made n_4 times.
2 appears in the first and the second group, therefore the latter must be made n_2 - n_4 times.
3 only appears in the last group, so this group must exist n_3 times.
Finally check that the amount of existing groups add to up n/3, and print each group the respective amount of times.

>>1307750
>Anything really, as long as it just gets the brain working.
>Ideally though I'm looking for less calculator based stuff and more mental maths, the sort that can come up in daily life.
learn how to use basic math to estimate or calculate numbers quickly. for example:
you want to estimate 190x71
190 = 200-10, 71 =70+1

then a quick estimation would be 190x71 ~= 200x70 = 2x7x100x10 = 14000.
for a better estimation, you substract 70x10 = 700, and you get 13300.
you get the final sum if you add 200-10 = 190: 13300 + 190 = 13490
what did I do here? I used the distributive property of addition and multiplication to make the actual calculation easier:
190x71 = (200-10)x(70+1) = 200x70 - 70x10 + 200 - 10


the actual calculation on paper, step by step:
190x71 = (200 - 10) x (70 + 1) = 200x70 + 200x1 - 10x70 - 10x1
= 2x7x100x10 + 200 - 7x100 - 10
= 14x1000 + 200 - 700 - 10
= 14000 - 500 - 10
= 13500 - 10
= 13400 + (100 - 10)
= 13490
this calculation takes many steps, but a quick estimation is far quicker if you know how to do it and are able to keep the numbers in your mind.

how do you use this in real life? say you are paying a bill: you bought 190 items at 71 cents each, and you want a quick estimation of how much it should cost before paying (so you don't get scammed or whatever), then you do this quick mental calculation and are able to estimate the final cost BEFORE paying anything.

posts.com: Hey guys how do I solve this? Do I unite the base and make the 8 as 2 power 3, 32 as 2 power 5? Is this correct?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: This is how I solved it, is it correct?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
"log" both sides, rearrange with log rules
log(8^(x-3)) = log((1/32)^x)
(x-3) log(8) = x log(1/32)

bring x terms to one side
(x-3)/x = log(1/32)/log(8)

x/x - 3/x = log(1/32)/log(8)
1 - 3/x = log(1/32)/log(8)
-3/x = log(1/32)/log(8) +1
-3/[log(1/32)/log(8)+1] = x

i guess
